comments.commentBody: And they are saying Occupy Wall Street is irrelevant. No wonder the elites want to convince us all of that.

"My gut tells me that this deficit of global leadership can’t last."

I am sure you are right about that. However, leadership can only come from new leaders. These guys have shown they can't, won't, don't even want to do it.

New leaders, really new and not just a change in sock puppets put up by present elites, will require some fundamental changes in our politics on the order of FDR sweeping in with the New Deal. That happened in part because he was seen as a safe, moderate choice in politics that also had charging forward Huey Long and Robert La Follette and the Business Coup group around Prescott Bush. It was fears of incipient revolutionary change that helped into power the New Deal as a moderate alternative.

We won't get new leadership until our elites are so terrified of more like Huey Long that they will allow the rise of an FDR.

The model decides how long a convention bounce should be by looking at historical bounces. It therefore expects that the bounce should have faded about three and a half weeks after the start of the convention; in this case Obama's bounce has about 6 days left until it should have totally faded.

Any improvement over the preconvention numbers that persist into this coming weekend and beyond should be considered either a convention bounce that didn't fade or a bounce from other factors (such as the 47% problem).

It would probably be difficult to attribute casualty, but the point is moot; it matters not why one candidate comes out of the post-convemtion period better than they went in, what matters to the model is that the numbers are presumed to become more stable beginning this weekend or next week. If the polls don't changr for the next week, it will no longer be reasonable to assume that Obama is benefitting from a temporary convention bounce; it will be reasonable to assume he has bounced uo to a relatively stable place.

http://fivethirtyeight.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/08/29/measuring-a-conventi...

I was surprised when I read as a youth about John Kennedy's constant pain from his rescuing another in the war, as when watching him he never seemed to show it. He was always witty and present, the only President I have seen who had a gift of really engaging with the press, in his unique, personal and charming way.

I was 13 when he was killed and remember feeling numb and disconnected, wondering how such a tragedy could happen, and how anyone could do something so horrendous.

For me, one of our nation's great Presidents, a man of vision, fearless and willing to speak his mind and live his ideals. Missing you today, Mr. President.

CO has had a huge number of voter issues. We have a high number of voters who vote by mail. The Sec of State Gessler went ahead and inactivated any person who receives a mail-in ballot and who did not vote in 2010.

But rest assured, the Dems are on it. All over the state we are knocking on the doors of any inactivated Dems or Unaffiliated voters and making sure they update their registrations. In my small town of 10,000 people (in a largely Republican county) we knocked on over 1,000 doors in one weekend. And this is happening weekend after weekend and in towns all over the state. It is our number 1 priority at the moment.

I'd also like to see an analysis of the possible impact of voter suppression efforts, and if possible also an attempt at analyzing the potential impact of differences in the two campaigns' "ground games." My current assumptions regarding these aspects of the campaign are as follows:

(1) Voter suppression efforts aimed against pro-Obama voters are most likely to successful in states where Republicans control the local levers of power, and those are are unlikely to be swing states anyway, so this will limit their impact on the electoral college.

(2) Suppression efforts are not new to this election, and are therefore already captured to some extend in existing polling models that distinguish between registered and likely voters. Suppression efforts that aim to formally disqualify legal voters are probably less common than informal efforts to discourage or confuse voters, such as flyers that give out incorrect election dates.)

(3) The Obama campaign is likely to have a better ground game than the Romney campaign, and this will offset the impact of voter suppression efforts aimed against pro-Obama voters. The Obama campaign had a very impressive ground game in 2008. This time around, it has had more time to build up its ground game while Romney was still trying just to win his primary (an advantage of incumbency). The Washington Post and other publications have reported that Obama's ground game is better-organized than Romney's in this election.
Matt, nice to hear from you.  There aren't many, if any of the theme answers I'd went to give up - I really loved them all, my favourite being the Long Highland Sound.

I am alienated from ALIENEE. ENOUNCE? I'm fine with it, as I am with enunciate. And SNOOK:

snook² [noun]
( Brit ) c**k a snook
a.to make a rude gesture by putting one thumb to the nose with the fingers of the hand outstretched.
b.to show contempt by being insulting or offensive [origin uncert.] From: Collins English Dictionary - Complete & Unabridged 10th Edition 2009 © William Collins Sons & Co. Ltd.

Yes, c**k is your standard, garden variety rooster.

Favorite theme entry: EYEBROW TWEEZERS.

I found the cross references just fine. I had L_ _ _ _ at 103D, which gave me both ABA and LSATS immediately.

This one had a funny theme with some great cluing and overall fine fill, but ATON of ENO, ONO, SST, ANET, ATAT, ETON, INON, ONEA. Nothing wrong with them per se, and a certain amount of junk fill is to be expected with so many theme answers in a large grid, but this was a little too much. It took away some of my solving pleasure.
P.S. My comment was sent from my Samsung Galaxy S III.

Sorry to be late with this comment. To the extent the iPhone adds to GDP it does so in a negative way -- more or less the same way buying gasoline adds to GDP. In both cases money changes hands thereby boosting formal GDP. But also in both cases much of the money is taken out of the economy. In the case of gasoline it goes to oil exporting countries. In the case of the iPhone the money sits relatively idle in Apple bank accounts.

GDP growth is good when additional money circulates. In these cases the money is effectively taken out of circulation, which is bad for the economy.

Forgot to add -- approx 1.2 million voters on the CO voters rolls were inactive. Of course some of these are legitimate, but 1.2 million in a state of approx. 5 million people is a pretty big portion (and of course, not all of those 5 million are eligible to vote).

I don't know if the statistics presented are correct so I have no quarrel with the economic arguments. The conclusions are debatable.  "As a result of residential segregation....." Low achievement as measured by current standardized tests only measure levels of poverty so duh.  I don't know what is meant by behavioral problems, but are these problems reported more in poverty schools? What are the tax expenditures that benefit high income families and how much should earned income credit be extended? How much more means testing can we stand?  Should we means test for social security and medicare?  Medicaid and TANF are already at a substandard subsistence level. And finally, don't lump RTTT, student loan reform and community college training in one pot and conclude that they all are poverty reducers. Each of these deserves its separate discussion, because none is a panacea and it may be questionable whether they are investments toward an income inequality cure, or a creation of more inequality in income, education, and of people of color.

As a native Miamian, I don't support the embargo. I think it is a huge mistake for now...52 years. What I think is most important, is for all of us to realize: Had not the people of Cuba been ground into poverty, Castro would not have been able to field an army. I think it is the strongest argument yet for why Education should be cheap, or free, why people should have enough to eat and proper medical care. Stick up for the middle class and your country will never have to experience what Cuba did. I traveled to Honduras and that's why some of it's country's have serious social issues. Capitalism gives those that want more an encentive, but when it runs amock , it leaves too many disadvantaged people.

I don't think it's the "neoliberal values," as much as the difficult economic times or, rather, the difference between today's economy and that of thirty-to-forty years ago:  Companies prefer to use add-ons (surcharges) rather than simply "padding-it-into" the base charge (think of the three-dollar cup of coffee at the end of dinner in a smart restaurant, instead of simply raising the entree-price two dollars, and the appetizer price one-dollar; they didn't do THAT either, in 1975) because they fear that, in today's difficult times, customers will be turned off by a higher basic fee, even if they suspect/know that they will ultimately pay more with all the add-ons. Since companies all fear that the competition will be doing the same thing, they will try to avoid raising the "basic" advertised/quoted charge, by almost any means possible. They also think that most customers are too disgusted to try to calculate what everything will ad up to, so they only look at basic fees when comparison-shopping. It all boils down to marketing-in-tough-economic-times 101. How to hook the customer when competition is fierce, times are tough, and impatience and ire rule the marketplace.
I just figured it out -- it was the Onion puzzle on June 6, by Matt Jones.  So many Matt's!  Anybody know how to contact him?

I agree with what Laszlo said, Matt, especially the part about how nice it was of you to stop by.

What I disagree with, from you mostly, is the thought of using fewer theme entries. You had a good theme and all of the theme entries were both strong and clever. That's what made this puzzle so enjoyable, and so Sunday-worthy. Sure, the less we see of pedestrian fill the better, but some is inevitable. I wouldn't want to sacrifice the really glittering theme entries just to get rid of it.
This puzzle was satisfying to complete; the theme was quite clever!  It's nice to be forced to think a bit. Looking forward to more from you.

This puzzle has a curious history. I constructed it 2-3 years ago, and as Will accepted it, he published a very similar puzzle but in the "other direction" -- it took phrases that *had* H's and dropped them, instead of the other way around.

Over the interval (and as we waited for the other puzzle not to be fresh in folks' minds), I think that crossword-dom has changed a bit. If I were making the puzzle now, I'd have used fewer theme entries and sparkled up the rest of the fill a bit. So I agree that the puzzle is a bit of a slog!

So, as always, I'm grateful to Deb for the tone of her review, and the apparent joy with which she met the theme answers while castigating me gently for the quality of what's left. I've got a few more puzzles in Will's queue, and hopefully they shine a bit more brightly!

Convergence is relative. But what I interpret him to be saying is that he has factored in adjustments to today's now-cast based on historical data that become less relevant as we approach election. For example, the 11/6 forecast made today includes adjustments for the convention bounce. By Sept 30 that adjustment is removed. If that adjustment were holding true, we'd expect that Obama's numbers would have continued to decline this week and next, until that adjustment was removed (and by his published graphs it is pretty clear that Nate has an average decay curve that adjusts the convention adjustment over time). The fact that Obama's numbers appear to be rising slightly over the past week suggests that the 11/6 forecast will move more towards the position of the now cast than vice-versa - hence his wording is technically more correct. This year's results will of course change the next cycle's decay curve to the extent that it deviates - and if I recall correctly, the decay curve is also adjusted for what party is in "power" at the time.

That said, there are factors that can't be incorporated into the forecast, unforeseen events for one, vice-presidential picks for another, but more importantly, performance in the debates. I, for one, am putting my money (figuratively) on Obama. He is the original come from behind kid. I think the turning point in the '08 elections came after the national debates. And Romney doesn't come remotely close to McCain in debate competence...
Don't forget his greatest love, the theocracy of Utah.

'personal awesomeness" and Mitt Romney do not belong in the same sentence. But while we are on the subject of confidence and the bold plan to turnaround the US economy, how is "we’ll see — without actually doing anything — we’ll actually get a boost in the economy" a plan?

Oh, and about that 'believe in America' slogan....how do the words victims, entitled, lack of personal responsibility, and, my personal favorite, "a lot of people feel extraordinarily complacent" demonstrate belief in a people? Send this man back to NH, CA, MA, and wherever else his home(s) is

Yes, I have questions about that as well. And not just the purges (and isn't it fascinating that all these years after the Cold War, we should find ourselves using that word about... us?), but all of the varied vote suppression tactics. I especially include the newly-brought-to-the-light-of-day, misogynistic "two forms of ID for married women" part of the Pennsylvania voter ID 'law'.

It seems like there are attacks on many fronts.

What say you, Nate?

Oren, I don't think you understand how partisan breakdown works.  You'd be hard pressed to find many Republicans in Portland, just as you'd probably be equally hard-pressed to find many Obama supporters in Eastern Oregon.

No, because the Now-Cast relies upon polls only.  As time wears on, the forecast will place less and less weight on economic indicators, meaning it will, indeed, converge with the Now-Cast.  The point you are trying to make is that the Now-Cast might also change as the polls change.

Sorry, but yours is the inaccuracy.  Tomorrow, election day will be nearer, but Nate isn't talking about tomorrow:  He's talking about a day very close to election day, a day when election day truly is near.

Thank you for the reminder of the global impact of American elections.  Romney can make fun of "healing the planet" all he wants, but whether we like it or not, the U.S. bears a special responsibility for taking the lead on global issues.  Since many Americans brag about being the best country in the world, and since the U.S. has clearly sought to be the world's dominant military and diplomatic power, it would behoove us to own up to our responsibilities.  Best regards to you and yours.

We're still in the "Obama convention bounce should retreat for a few more days" time period, so the Nov 6 forecast assumes a point or two shift back to Romney. If that doesn't happen within the next week's polls, it'll go Toss-up at least.
If Nate were to address this weekly, you'd get far less new and current information. Please use the search function, as he has indeed addressed it before.

hayford.
Jay Cost and Jen Rubin. They raged at Nate the last time Romney's win probability dropped below 20% in the forecast.

yah, Jesse, its folded into the FORECAST.
There is nothing in the nowcast that prevents Romney's win probability from approaching zero.
Nate said it was poll based only.

Mark, ACC, et.al who say Obama offers "nonsense;" here's your chance to persuade me to vote for Romney! On domestic issues:

He said in July not taking every deduction to reduce taxes disqualifes him to be President--then he rolled over deductions to pay more taxes for political reasons (a 13% rate vs. 9%). I'm stunned. Can I trust his word?

On a night darkened by grief and violence, (a time when Americans needed strong aaccord), Romney pushed his blame points. Was that the time and place for his actions; can he be Presidential?

His pitch to $50K donors was "inelegant." To such "groups" he pitched business deals worth millions, deals he had to win and close. Why was he "inelegant" about his deep views of citizens?

Can we agree he misrepresents Obama's waiver of fed welfare regulations requested by many red states? Does Romney stand for states rights, or firm federal control and Washington mandates?

The market has not lowered health care costs. Called premium support or vouchers, how will the market lower costs and provide seniors with the same comprehensive coverage?

What are the secret tax loop holes he plans to close? Is it a back room, "inside" deal? As a voter, don't I deserve to know?

The XL is a 30 in, pipeline--706 1in. hoses. Refineries are booked, drilling takes years. How will he produce energy independence?

I doubt that will happen. The House is a messy business, polling data is so patchy relative to the Senate, and so many local phenomena impinge.

That said, if Mr. Silver wishes to wade in, his guess will likely be better than most.

I don't understand your criticism, KKV. There is no direction implicit in "converge" is there?
Although Nate could have simply just said ". . . the forecast and now-cast will converge," his meaning was quite clear. No "vice-versa" is necessary.
